Problem:
Consider a function \\( z = f(x, y) \\) defined over complex numbers, where \\( f(x, y) = e^{Ax + By} \\) with A and B being constant complex matrices. This scenario explores the behavior of \\( z \\) under the linear transformations \\( T_x(x, y) = (x+1, y) \\) and \\( T_y(x, y) = (x, y+1) \\).

If the transformations \\( T_x \\) and \\( T_y \\) are applied to the variables \(x, y\) at time \( t = 0 \), and then \( z \) evolves according to \( f(x, y) \) without further interventions, will the value of \( z(t) \) at \( t = T \) be the same as if \( (x, y) \) was directly evolved to \( t = T \) under \( f(x, y) \)?
Explanation: Applying \( T_x \) and \( T_y \) changes the arguments of \( f \) linearly, altering the exponential map. Since \( e^{A(x+1) + B(y+1)} \) differs from \( e^{Ax + By} \) by factors of \( e^A \) and \( e^B \), the trajectory and hence the value of \( z(t) \) will be different.
